column4: idk i cant see what it detects only tell it to look for something
does 'iwscan ap' say anything? (is that even the right syntax?)
'iwlist ap'
define 'any'   What were the interface names it gave?
how are you trying to make it work? (which program? the little gnome toolbar applet thing?)
should work ;)
try setting the essid manually: 'iwconfig wlan0 essid <whatever it is>'
so the gnome applet sees the netgear ESSID?
if so, ignore my previous suggestion
try setting the essid manually
if 'iwlist ap'  isn't showin anything, it means 1 of 3 things: 1) there aren't any APs in range 2) your stuff's broke 3) other
I'm just trying to isolate it
try to isolate where the problem is (set essid manually, then set IP manually and that sort of thing, and do ping tests and all that)
start by pinging the IP of your Access Point (AP), then move on to something further away
I assume your access point works with whatever you're using to connect right now?
again, try to isolate where the problem is (set essid manually, then set IP manually and that sort of thing, and do ping tests and all that)
if the router is working, then the system must be wrong.  Set things manually to reasonable values and see if it works
it may end up being that the driver the system (or you, if you pickked it) is using for your wireless card is wrong.
they're separate hardware on the router, the wirelss and the ethernet
sunspots?
sunspots are more likely...it's well-known that they interfere with certain RF applications ;)
I'm beingfacetious, of course, (sunspots only affect long wavelength propogation :P)..  But yeah, try and set some stuff manually, tell me how it goes.
Sorry I'm not better help.  Wifi is one of those things that isn't very consistent :)
I mean ... invisible waves of electromagnetic energy? wtf?
